thread.title: Gold on track for biggest monthly drop in 2 years
thread.title_full: Gold on track for biggest monthly drop in 2 years - MarketWatch

author: By     William Watts
title: Gold on track for biggest monthly drop in 2 years
text:
Gold futures edged higher Friday after a weaker-than-expected rise in U.S. labor costs, but remain on track to end an ugly July with the biggest monthly decline in more than two years.
Gold for August delivery on Comex GCQ5, +0.42% erased early weakness to gain $1.20, or 0.1%, to $1,089.60 an ounce. December gold GCZ5, +0.40% which is now the most actively traded contract, was up $1.10, or 0.1%, to $1,089.80 an ounce after earlier trading as low as $1,079.20.
The yellow metal saw relief from selling pressure after the Labor Department said its employment cost index rose a record low 0.2% in the second quarter, well below the 0.7% rise penciled in by economists surveyed by MarketWatch. Weaker labor costs could give the Federal Reserve a reason to hold off on delivering a rate hike that investors have largely penciled in for later this year.
See: Sharp deceleration in employment costs gives Fed a reason to delay rate hikes .
Expectations for a Fed rate hike—and the resulting strength in the dollar—have been credited with driving gold and other commodities lower. Higher rates make commodities, which offer no yield, less attractive. A stronger dollar can weigh on commodities priced in the unit by making them more expensive to users of other currencies.
Some analysts, however, argue that concerns about global financial stability amid continued tensions over Greece and China’s stock-market rout might be a bigger factor, despite the fact gold is typically seen as a haven during times of turmoil.
“The global financial picture is precarious and one might assume that weakness in gold is more a generation of liquidity needs as opposed to a fundamental negativity,” wrote Peter Hug, global trading director at Kitco Metals Inc.
Gold remains on track to end July with a 7.1% monthly loss on a most-active basis, the steepest drop since June 2013, according to FactSet.
In other metals trade, September silver SIU5, +0.67% fell 0.6 cent to $14.69 an ounce.
October platinum PLV5, -0.58% lost $10, or 1%, to $979.90 an ounce, while September palladium PAU5, -1.74% fell $11.55, or 1.9%, to $609 an ounce.
September copper HGU5, -0.32% lost 0.45 cent, or 0.2%, to $2.3275 a pound,
